BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Gradual increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of the snowfall.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh snow as well as the large wind slabs that are forming above all adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls can be released very easily in all aspects above approximately 1800 m. As a consequence of the snowfall, the likelihood of ground avalanches being released will increase gradually in particular on steep southeast and southwest facing slopes at intermediate altitudes. The soft wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence above approximately 2000 m. In all aspects and on wind-loaded slopes numerous large and, in isolated cases, very large avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: These conditions will cause a rise in the danger of dry and moist avalanches in all aspects.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights:
A lot of snow has fallen in some regions.
In the regions exposed to heavier precipitation the avalanche danger is higher.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh snow as well as the wind slabs represent the main danger. This applies in particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation.
In all aspects large and, in isolated cases, very large avalanches are possible as a consequence of new snow and strong wind. The new snow and wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects. In addition the barely recognisable wind slabs should be taken into account. Gliding avalanches are possible in particular on steep grassy slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Some snow will fall in some regions.
The fresh snow as well as the resulting wind slabs remain for the foreseeable future prone to triggering.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Weakly bonded old snow represents the main danger. Fresh wind slabs require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Avalanches can be triggered in the old snowpack and reach large size in isolated cases in particular on very steep west, north and east facing slopes. Such avalanche prone locations are to be found above approximately 2400 m.

Above the tree line the wind slabs will increase in size additionally. Even single winter sport participants can release avalanches, including medium-sized ones, especially on steep shady slopes. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude.

On steep grassy slopes medium-sized gliding avalanches are possible, especially on sunny slopes below approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 20 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 1500 m. As a consequence of the sometimes strong wind the wind slabs will increase in size additionally.

In some cases new snow and wind slabs are lying on a weakly bonded old snowpack, in particular on steep west, north and east facing slopes above approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The conditions will prevent a rapid stabilisation of the snowpack. In addition further gliding avalanches are to be expected. Some loose snow avalanches are possible, in the event of prolonged bright spells in particular on extremely steep slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Even single backcountry tourers can release avalanches as before.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Since Friday the wind has been moderate at times in particular along the border with France and along the border with Switzerland.
As a consequence of wind from westerly directions, sometimes deep wind slabs formed in the last two days.
They can be released easily by a single winter sport participant, especially on very steep slopes, caution is to be exercised in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Reports filed by observers and artificially triggered avalanches have confirmed this situation.
Remotely triggered avalanches are possible in isolated cases, especially along the border with France.
Backcountry touring calls for meticulous route selection. Maintaining distances between individuals and one-at-a-time descents are recommended.
Natural avalanches: Dry slab avalanches and dry loose snow avalanches are possible in isolated cases as before, especially adjacent to ridgelines.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Some snow will fall from the afternoon.
30 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell on Thursday. The moderate wind has transported the new snow.
The wind slabs remain in some cases prone to triggering in particular on very steep shady slopes.
Since Friday in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain many small and medium-sized avalanches were released.
On the night between Thursday and Friday: Numerous medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large dry slab avalanches have been released on wind-loaded slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Some snow will fall on Monday. The danger will persist.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs: At intermediate and high altitudes a considerable avalanche danger will prevail.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Above approximately 1100 m snow fell on Thursday. Over a wide area over a wide area 20 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 2000 m. The wind was moderate in the vicinity of peaks.
The more recent wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant and generally at intermediate and high altitudes. They are to be found especially adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Wind and new snow above approximately 1100 m. The sometimes strong wind has transported the new snow significantly. In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust. Faceted weak layers exist in the old snowpack on steep shady slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of the snowfall the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Weakly bonded old snow requires caution. Loose snow avalanches and gliding avalanches are still possible.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released in some places even by individual winter sport participants. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on west, north and east facing slopes above approximately 2400 m. Avalanches can reach large size in isolated cases.
Fresh avalanches and whumpfing sounds serve as an alarm indicating the danger.

In addition the wind slabs of the last few days are capable of being triggered in some cases. Such avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on very steep shady slopes above the tree line, caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas. These places are sometimes covered with new snow and are therefore difficult to recognise.

As the day progresses more small and medium-sized loose snow avalanches are possible, in the event of solar radiation especially. On steep grassy slopes small and medium-sized gliding avalanches are possible as a consequence of the new snow, especially on sunny slopes below approximately 2400 m.

Backcountry touring and other off-piste activities call for careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
5 to 10 cm of snow will fall on Sunday. The wind will be moderate adjacent to ridgelines.

The new snow and wind slabs of Friday are lying on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack in particular on west to north to east facing aspects above approximately 2400 m. Fresh wind slabs are lying on soft layers on near-ridge shady slopes. Somewhat older wind slabs are covered with new snow and therefore barely recognisable.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
Weakly bonded old snow represents the main danger.
The danger of gliding avalanches will persist.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and weakly bonded old snow represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The avalanche danger in particular at elevated altitudes is within the uppermost range of danger level 3 (considerable). A very large quantity of fresh snow and the sometimes large wind slabs that are being formed by the strong to storm force southerly wind can be released very easily in all aspects above approximately 2200 m. Individual occasionally large natural avalanches are possible, especially in case of releases originating from very steep high-altitude shady starting zones. Avalanches can also be triggered in the old snowpack and reach large size in particular on very steep west, north and east facing slopes. Such avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular above approximately 2400 m.

On steep grassy slopes medium-sized gliding avalanches are possible as a consequence of the new snow, especially on sunny slopes below approximately 2400 m.

Backcountry touring and other off-piste activities call for great caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Up to 70 cm of snow fell on Friday above approximately 1500 m. Up to 10 cm of snow will fall on Sunday. The southerly wind will transport the new snow significantly. In some cases new snow and wind slabs are lying on a weakly bonded old snowpack, in particular on steep west and east facing slopes above approximately 2400 m, as well as on steep north facing slopes above approximately 2200 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
The weather conditions will prevent a rapid stabilisation of the near-surface layers.
The danger of gliding avalanches will persist, in particular on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2400 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the wind slabs represent the main danger. Loose snow avalanches are to be expected.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The large quantity of fresh snow and the sometimes deep wind slabs can be released easily or naturally in all aspects. As a consequence of the moderate to strong southwesterly wind the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent. Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large natural avalanches are to be expected, especially in case of releases originating from very steep leeward starting zones. The avalanche prone locations are covered with new snow and are barely recognisable, even to the trained eye. An increasing number of medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large loose snow avalanches are to be expected as the day progresses, in the event of prolonged bright spells especially. Avalanches can also be triggered in the old snowpack and reach quite a large size.
On steep grassy slopes medium-sized gliding avalanches are possible.
Backcountry touring and other off-piste activities call for great caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 25 to 50 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Friday above approximately 1400 m. The strong wind has transported some snow.
The new snow and wind slabs are lying on a crust in all aspects below approximately 2400 m.
The new snow and wind slabs are poorly bonded with the old snowpack. Especially shady slopes above approximately 2400 m:
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Loose snow avalanches are possible, but they can be quite large, in the regions exposed to a lot of new snow especially on very steep slopes. The weather conditions will prevent a rapid stabilisation of the near-surface layers.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow represents the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As the day progresses as a consequence of the snowfall there will be an increase in the danger of moist and wet avalanches to level 2 (moderate).

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Individual avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular on very steep shady slopes. In addition gliding avalanches and snow slides are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The new snow and wind slabs of Friday can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases in particular on very steep shady slopes above the tree line, caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas. These places are sometimes covered with new snow and are therefore difficult to recognise. Mostly avalanches are only small.

As the day progresses mostly small loose snow avalanches are possible, in the event of solar radiation especially.
On steep grassy slopes small to medium-sized gliding avalanches are possible as a consequence of the new snow. Caution is to be exercised in areas with glide cracks.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Some snow will fall on Sunday. The wind will be moderate adjacent to ridgelines.

The fresh and older wind slabs are lying on soft layers on near-ridge shady slopes.

The solar radiation will give rise as the day progresses to moistening of the snowpack in particular on sunny slopes. Only a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Individual gliding avalanches and snow slides are possible, but they will be mostly small. Wind slabs are now only very rarely prone to triggering.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Above approximately 1500 m snow fell on Thursday. The fresh snow of the last two days and in particular the sometimes deep wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant, in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas in particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. In the regions exposed to heavier precipitation caution is to be exercised in particular on steep slopes along the border with France.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area over a wide area 15 to 25 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell on Thursday above approximately 2000 m. Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust.
Large-grained weak layers exist in the snowpack in particular on shady slopes. The old snowpack remains generally stable.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of the snowfall the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: At elevated altitudes the avalanche prone locations are more widespread and the danger is level 2 (moderate).
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Above approximately 1500 m snow fell on Thursday.
The fresh snow of the last two days and in particular the mostly small wind slabs can be released in isolated cases, in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas in particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. In the regions exposed to heavier precipitation this applies in particular on very steep slopes.
Apart from the danger of being buried, restraint should be exercised as well in view of the danger of avalanches sweeping people along and giving rise to falls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The new snow is deposited on bare ground over a wide area. This applies in particular on sunny slopes, as well as at low and intermediate altitudes.
In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust.
The old snowpack remains generally stable.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of the snowfall the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of a sometimes moderate wind from westerly directions, wind slabs formed in the last two days.
They can be released. These avalanche prone locations are to be found on very steep slopes and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude.
Natural avalanches: More avalanches are possible, but they will be mostly small, especially on extremely steep slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Some snow will fall in the evening.
20 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell on Thursday above approximately 2000 m.
The fresh snow as well as the wind slabs are bonding only slowly with the old snowpack in particular on shady slopes.
The old snowpack is favourably layered.
At low and intermediate altitudes only a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Some snow will fall on Monday. The danger will increase a little during the day.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs at intermediate and high altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
5 to 15 cm of snow fell on Thursday above approximately 2000 m. The mostly small wind slabs can be released in some cases in particular on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2300 m. This applies in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas in particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions.
Apart from the danger of being buried, restraint should be exercised as well in view of the danger of avalanches sweeping people along and giving rise to falls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The new snow is deposited on bare ground over a wide area. This applies in particular on sunny slopes, as well as at low and intermediate altitudes.
In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust.
The old snowpack remains generally stable.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of the snowfall the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs at intermediate and high altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
5 to 15 cm of snow fell on Thursday above approximately 2000 m. The mostly small wind slabs can be released in some cases in particular on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2300 m. This applies in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas in particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions.
Apart from the danger of being buried, restraint should be exercised as well in view of the danger of avalanches sweeping people along and giving rise to falls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The new snow is deposited on bare ground over a wide area. This applies in particular on sunny slopes, as well as at low and intermediate altitudes.
In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust.
The old snowpack remains generally stable.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of the snowfall the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Individual avalanche prone locations are to be found at intermediate and high altitudes and on very steep slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of a mostly light wind from westerly directions, small wind slabs formed.
These can in isolated cases be released by people.
The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on very steep slopes and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain.
Restraint should be exercised because avalanches can sweep people along and give rise to falls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Some snow will fall in the evening.
10 to 20 cm of snow fell on Thursday above approximately 1900 m.
The old snowpack will be in most cases well bonded.
Snow depths vary greatly at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions, depending on the infuence of the wind.
At low and intermediate altitudes only a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Some snow will fall on Monday. The danger will increase during the day.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Weakly bonded old snow is to be evaluated with care and prudence. Precarious weak layers exist in the old snowpack in gullies and bowls.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Individual mostly small avalanches are possible above approximately 1800 m. This applies especially in gullies and bowls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack remains subject to considerable local variations. At high altitude only a little snow is lying. At high altitude mostly small wind slabs formed. In gullies and bowls the wind slabs are larger.
